qas.question: When was reinvent the toilet launched

answers.text: In 2011, the foundation launched a program called "Reinvent the Toilet Challenge

qas.question: What is the aim of reinvent the toilet

answers.text: to promote the development of innovations in toilet design to benefit the 2.5 billion people that do not have access to safe and effective sanitation

qas.question: WHat program compliment reinvent the toilet

answers.text: It was complemented by a program called "Grand Challenges Explorations" (2011 to 2013 with some follow-up grants reaching until 2015)

qas.question: What was excluded by the funding schemes

answers.text: Both funding schemes explicitly excluded project ideas that relied on centralized sewerage systems or are not compatible with development country contexts

qas.question: In 2011 what program was launched by Grand Challenges Exploration?
What program generated interest by Grand Challenges Explorations?

plausible_answers.text: project ideas that relied on centralized sewerage systems or are not compatible with development country contexts.

qas.question: What program complimented innovations in toilet design?

plausible_answers.text: to promote the development of innovations in toilet design to benefit the 2.5 billion people that do not have access to safe and effective sanitation

qas.question: What was the aim of Grand Challenges Explorations?

context: <a0_0>In 2011, the foundation launched a program called "<b4_0><b5_0>Reinvent the Toilet Challenge<b5_0/><b4_0/><a0_0/>" with the aim <a1_0><b8_0>to promote the development of innovations in toilet design to benefit the 2.5 billion people that do not have access to safe and effective sanitation<b8_0/><a1_0/>. This program has generated significant interest of the mainstream media. <a2_0>It was complemented by a program called "<b7_0>Grand Challenges Explorations"<b7_0/> (2011 to 2013 with some follow-up grants reaching until 2015)<a2_0/> which involved grants of US$100,000 each in the first round. <a3_0>Both funding schemes explicitly excluded <b6_0>project ideas that relied on centralized sewerage systems or are not compatible with development country contexts<a3_0/>.
